descriptionSet.description: An indian female dancer wearing traditional clothes while performing.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: An indian female dancer wearing traditional clothes while performing. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Usually the only women we see in colonial postcards are native, as we see in "Girl Dancing like Peacock". (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The native women in this postcard is subject to the same picturesque aesthetic the native landscapes that she inhabited were subjected to. However, one wonders, why when it was deemed appropriate to show a Begum in her boudoir, the white woman or "memsahib" rarely was. Where was the memsahib in the imagery? It is not that white women were completely absent from colonial postcards. The European women who were depicted in the postcards were usually missionaries or travelers, and within the colonial school room sub-genre, the only European in the image was often the white school mistress.Therefore, the spaces they occupied in these images were either defined by the "good works" they performed, or by their journeys to exotic locations. The private realm of the memsahib was in "purdah" so to speak. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
